  - "Should we build MCP tools now or wait for user approval of design?"

metadata.context_summary:
Designed and built comprehensive personal log feature for Santiago PM.
Started with completed personal-log-discovery-questionnaire.md where user
provided detailed responses about context loss pain points, chat history
needs, and semantic linking requirements. User also dropped hints about
3 future features (conversational UI, vector DB, performance optimization).
metadata.summary:
Completed full personal log feature design and MVP implementation:

1. Analyzed questionnaire responses (10 questions with rich insights)
2. Extracted 6 key insights including MVP focus (context restoration)
3. Designed hybrid structure (personal-logs/ + captains-journals/)
4. Created 3 folders (agents/, humans/, archive/)
5. Built comprehensive README.md (use cases, semantic linking, success metrics)
6. Created 2 templates (chat-history-template.md, personal-log-template.md)
7. Designed 9 MCP tools (3 MVP, 3 enhanced, 3 team coordination)
8. Documented this conversation as first agent personal log (this file!)

Total artifacts: 7 new files, ~2,000 lines of documentation

key_decisions.decision: Use hybrid structure (Option C) with personal-logs/ and captains-journals/
key_decisions.rationale: User responses indicated two distinct log types (agents vs humans) with different formats and frequencies. Agents need chat history preservation, humans need journal structure. Hybrid accommodates both while maintaining clear separation from ships-logs (team issues).
alternatives_considered: Option B: Only captains-journals/ (repurpose existing folder)

key_decisions.decision: Preserve original chat format (minimal transformation)
key_decisions.rationale: User emphasized importance of not losing context during conversion. Copilot has its own format - preserve it exactly to avoid information loss. Metadata layer adds structure without altering core content.

key_decisions.decision: Automatic generation for agents, manual for humans (with suggestions)
key_decisions.rationale: User specified agents should always save (capture everything) but humans need flexibility. Santiago can suggest structure while allowing freeform expression.
alternatives_considered: Automatic for both (may feel invasive for humans)

key_decisions.decision: Personal logs are public to team (not private)
key_decisions.rationale: User stated logs will be loaded into Santiago PM KG and used for team coordination, learning, and decision-making. Must warn humans that logs are team-visible.

questions: How to handle Copilot's native chat format? Need to inspect actual format to preserve correctly.
Should we build MCP tools now or wait for user approval of design?
How to prioritize the 3 new feature hints discovered? (conversational UI, vector DB, performance)
learning: Questionnaire pattern is powerful for discovery - user provided 3 feature hints we didn't ask for!
Personal logs serve multiple use cases (context restoration, billing, learning, coordination)
Semantic linking is the key value proposition - logs alone are useful, but linking to artifacts makes them invaluable
User's insight about 'rate limiter' (file I/O performance) suggests we should think about scaling early
next_steps: Save this conversation as first agent personal log (proof-of-concept)
Create cargo-manifest for personal-log-feature implementation
Get user approval of design before building MCP tools
Add 3 discovered features to backlog (conversational UI, vector DB, performance)

items.title: AI agents lose context when switching models
items.description:
User had completed the personal-log-discovery-questionnaire.md with detailed responses to 10 questions. The questionnaire asked about context loss pain points, log frequency, information capture needs, structure preferences, and integration requirements.

Key user responses included:
- Primary pain point: AI agents lose context when switching models
- Two distinct use cases: agents (chat history) vs humans (journal)
- MVP success: New agent reads log and restores context without re-explanation
- Semantic linking to artifacts is critical for future value

needs, and semantic linking requirements. User also dropped hints about

metadata.summary:
Completed full personal log feature design and MVP implementation:

1. Analyzed questionnaire responses (10 questions with rich insights)
2. Extracted 6 key insights including MVP focus (context restoration)
3. Designed hybrid structure (personal-logs/ + captains-journals/)
4. Created 3 folders (agents/, humans/, archive/)
5. Built comprehensive README.md (use cases, semantic linking, success metrics)
6. Created 2 templates (chat-history-template.md, personal-log-template.md)
7. Designed 9 MCP tools (3 MVP, 3 enhanced, 3 team coordination)
8. Documented this conversation as first agent personal log (this file!)

Total artifacts: 7 new files, ~2,000 lines of documentation

key_decisions.decision: Use hybrid structure (Option C) with personal-logs/ and captains-journals/
key_decisions.rationale: User responses indicated two distinct log types (agents vs humans) with different formats and frequencies. Agents need chat history preservation, humans need journal structure. Hybrid accommodates both while maintaining clear separation from ships-logs (team issues).
alternatives_considered: Option B: Only captains-journals/ (repurpose existing folder)

key_decisions.decision: Preserve original chat format (minimal transformation)
key_decisions.rationale: User emphasized importance of not losing context during conversion. Copilot has its own format - preserve it exactly to avoid information loss. Metadata layer adds structure without altering core content.

key_decisions.decision: Automatic generation for agents, manual for humans (with suggestions)
key_decisions.rationale: User specified agents should always save (capture everything) but humans need flexibility. Santiago can suggest structure while allowing freeform expression.
alternatives_considered: Automatic for both (may feel invasive for humans)

key_decisions.decision: Personal logs are public to team (not private)
key_decisions.rationale: User stated logs will be loaded into Santiago PM KG and used for team coordination, learning, and decision-making. Must warn humans that logs are team-visible.

questions: How to handle Copilot's native chat format? Need to inspect actual format to preserve correctly.
Should we build MCP tools now or wait for user approval of design?
How to prioritize the 3 new feature hints discovered? (conversational UI, vector DB, performance)
learning: Questionnaire pattern is powerful for discovery - user provided 3 feature hints we didn't ask for!
Personal logs serve multiple use cases (context restoration, billing, learning, coordination)
Semantic linking is the key value proposition - logs alone are useful, but linking to artifacts makes them invaluable
User's insight about 'rate limiter' (file I/O performance) suggests we should think about scaling early
next_steps: Save this conversation as first agent personal log (proof-of-concept)
Create cargo-manifest for personal-log-feature implementation
Get user approval of design before building MCP tools
Add 3 discovered features to backlog (conversational UI, vector DB, performance)

# Artifacts

metadata.author: Hank
metadata.context_summary:
Reviewing the domain knowledge extraction BDD feature with Santiago.
Realized the test scenarios need actual executable tests + evolving test data.
This led to discovering a much larger feature: comprehensive workflow test data system.
metadata.summary:
- Reviewed BDD feature for personal log domain knowledge extraction
- Identified gap: BDD scenarios aren't executable tests yet
- Discovered need for evolving project test data (hard problem!)
- Recognized Santiago's unique capability: track state evolution (git + KG over time)
- Extracted multiple new features from this reflection
- Provided feedback on personal log feature itself (meta!)
mentioned: Lean-Kanban workflow patterns (need test data for gates, sequences, state transitions)
Git state tracking (Santiago sees asset evolution)
Knowledge graph evolution (Santiago sees knowledge state over time)
Multiple Santiago agents coordinating (PM, UX, Dev, Ethicist)

key_decisions.decision: BDD scenarios need to be executable with pytest-bdd or behave
key_decisions.rationale: Current .feature file is documentation only. Need actual test harness to validate Santiago behaviors.
alternatives_considered: Write custom test runner (rejected - reinventing wheel)
Use pytest-bdd (chosen - integrates with existing pytest suite)

key_decisions.decision: Need evolving test data system for workflow testing
key_decisions.rationale:
Testing workflows requires realistic project state that evolves over time:
- Backlog with items in different states (new, in-progress, blocked, done)
- Knowledge graph that grows as work progresses
- Git history showing artifact evolution
- Multiple agents working concurrently
- Human interactions and decisions

This is a HARD PROBLEM but crucial for testing Lean-Kanban patterns, gates,
concurrency control, and multi-agent coordination.
alternatives_considered: Generate fresh each test (rejected - loses temporal patterns)
Evolving test data that accumulates (chosen - matches reality)

key_decisions.decision: Santiago's time-aware capabilities are key differentiator
key_decisions.rationale:
Santiago can see:
- Git history (when artifacts changed, by whom, what changed)
- KG evolution (when knowledge added, decisions made, relationships formed)
- State transitions (when work items moved through workflow)

This temporal awareness enables:
- Learning from past patterns
- Detecting anomalies (why is this taking longer than usual?)
- Coordination (who's working on what, what's blocked, what's next?)
- Provenance (why did we make this decision? when? what was context?)

key_decisions.decision: This log entry itself demonstrates feature extraction pattern
key_decisions.rationale:
Meta-observation: This personal log mentions multiple features
and provides feedback on the personal log system itself.

If Santiago-PM reads this, it should:
1. Detect feature mentions (workflow test data system)
2. Detect feedback on personal log feature (BDD needs executable tests)
3. Create tasks for each discovery
4. Assess priority based on context (hard problem, key differentiator)
5. Link back to this log (provenance)

This is exactly the behavior we designed in the BDD scenarios!

questions: How to structure evolving test data? Git submodule? Separate repo? In-tree?
Should test data accumulate across test runs or reset each time?
How to handle temporal queries in tests? (e.g., 'what was KG state 3 commits ago?')
Do we need test data fixtures for each Santiago maturity level (Apprentice/Journeyman/Master)?
How do other projects handle evolving workflow test data? (Research needed)
learning: BDD scenarios are great documentation but need executable implementation
Workflow testing is fundamentally different from unit testing (state, time, coordination)
Santiago's temporal awareness (git + KG history) is unique and powerful
Personal logs are highly generative - this one log spawned 4+ new features
Meta-pattern: Testing the personal log feature by creating a personal log about testing
metadata.mood: Excited - this is a hard problem but Santiago is uniquely positioned to solve it
metadata.next_session:
1. Create cargo manifest for "Workflow Test Data System" feature
2. Research: How do other systems test evolving workflows? (Temporal, Cadence, etc.)
3. Design test data structure (fixtures vs accumulating vs hybrid)
4. Implement executable tests for domain knowledge extraction BDD
5. Extract other features mentioned in this log (list below)

alternatives_considered: Write custom test runner (rejected - reinventing wheel)
Use pytest-bdd (chosen - integrates with existing pytest suite)

key_decisions.decision: Need evolving test data system for workflow testing
key_decisions.rationale:
Testing workflows requires realistic project state that evolves over time:
- Backlog with items in different states (new, in-progress, blocked, done)
- Knowledge graph that grows as work progresses
- Git history showing artifact evolution
- Multiple agents working concurrently
- Human interactions and decisions

This is a HARD PROBLEM but crucial for testing Lean-Kanban patterns, gates,
concurrency control, and multi-agent coordination.
alternatives_considered: Generate fresh each test (rejected - loses temporal patterns)
Evolving test data that accumulates (chosen - matches reality)

key_decisions.decision: Santiago's time-aware capabilities are key differentiator
key_decisions.rationale:
Santiago can see:
- Git history (when artifacts changed, by whom, what changed)
- KG evolution (when knowledge added, decisions made, relationships formed)
- State transitions (when work items moved through workflow)

This temporal awareness enables:
- Learning from past patterns
- Detecting anomalies (why is this taking longer than usual?)
- Coordination (who's working on what, what's blocked, what's next?)
- Provenance (why did we make this decision? when? what was context?)

key_decisions.decision: This log entry itself demonstrates feature extraction pattern
key_decisions.rationale:
Meta-observation: This personal log mentions multiple features
and provides feedback on the personal log system itself.

If Santiago-PM reads this, it should:
1. Detect feature mentions (workflow test data system)
2. Detect feedback on personal log feature (BDD needs executable tests)
3. Create tasks for each discovery
4. Assess priority based on context (hard problem, key differentiator)
5. Link back to this log (provenance)

This is exactly the behavior we designed in the BDD scenarios!

questions: How to structure evolving test data? Git submodule? Separate repo? In-tree?
Should test data accumulate across test runs or reset each time?
How to handle temporal queries in tests? (e.g., 'what was KG state 3 commits ago?')
Do we need test data fixtures for each Santiago maturity level (Apprentice/Journeyman/Master)?
How do other projects handle evolving workflow test data? (Research needed)
learning: BDD scenarios are great documentation but need executable implementation
Workflow testing is fundamentally different from unit testing (state, time, coordination)
Santiago's temporal awareness (git + KG history) is unique and powerful
Personal logs are highly generative - this one log spawned 4+ new features
Meta-pattern: Testing the personal log feature by creating a personal log about testing
metadata.mood: Excited - this is a hard problem but Santiago is uniquely positioned to solve it
